item.title: CPUs And Graphics Cards From AMD, Intel, And Nvidia Are On Sale For Prime Day
item.content:encoded:

We're halfway through Amazon's Prime Day 2025 Sale, but there's still plenty of deals to check out in this year's four-day event, including some awesome discounts on CPUs and graphics cards from AMD, Intel, and Nvidia. We've rounded up some of our favorite deals on PC components into the lists below, plus a selection of discounted pre-built gaming PCs. Prime Day runs until July 11, unless they sell out before then, so make sure you grab the discounted components while you can. For more deals on PC gaming gear, video games, and other electronics, be sure to check GameSpot's Prime Day Deals Hub.

AMD Ryzen CPU Prime Day Deals

Some of the best deals are available for AMD's Ryzen CPUs, which are nearly 50% off on select models. The biggest discount is for the Ryzen 9 7900X 12-core 24-thread Unlocked CPU, which is down to $288 (was $550). This is a solid CPU that can work well for PC gaming, and since it's unlocked . However, if you're looking for something more powerful, the Ryzen 9 9950X is now available for $434 (down from $650), making it a great pick for anyone building an AMD-based gaming PC. Check the list below for a few other AMD Ryzen CPUs are included in the sale, or browse the full AMD lineup at Amazon.

  • AMD Ryzen 9 9950X CPU - $434 ($650)
  • AMD Ryzen 9 7950X CPU - $435 ($700)
  • AMD Ryzen 9 7900X CPU - $288 ($550)
  • AMD Ryzen 5 7600X CPU - $160 ($300)

Intel CPU Prime Day Deals

For those who prefer Intel-based hardware, there's a long list of Intel CPUs on sale as well. For a good PC gaming pick, the Intel Core i9-14900K CPU is down to $364 (was $439). This model uses Intel's 14th Gen CPU technology and offers a max 6 GHz clock speed. It also features Intel's integrated graphics tech, meaning you don't technically need a GPU if you're building a new rig (though we suggest grabbing an Nvidia GeForce or AMD Radeon GPU if you're parting out a PC gaming desktop).

Several other Intel CPUs are on sale during Prime Day, and we've listed a few more below. You can also browse the full lineup of Intel deals at Amazon.

  • Intel Core i9-14900K CPU -- $364 ($439)
  • Intel Core i7-14700K CPU -- $272 ($321)
  • Intel Core Ultra 9 285K CPU -- $490 ($600)
  • Intel Core Ultra 7 265K CPU -- $260 ($404)

Nvidia GeForce RTX Graphic Card Prime Day Deals

If you need a graphics card to go along with your new CPU, a few Nvidia GeForce RTX GPUs are also on sale, including a few OC Edition (meaning overclocked) RTX 5000 series GPUs from Asus. The more powerful option is the Asus TUF Gaming GeForce RTX 5070 OC Edition, which features 12GB GDDR7 VRAM and is on sale for $685 (was $740).

For a more affordable option, the Asus Dual GeForce RTX 5060 Ti 16GB model is slightly discounted to $430 (was $480). The 5060 Ti is a step down in terms of power from the 5070; however, the 16GB GDDR7 on this model is great for playing on 1440p or 4K displays. There's also a discount on an Asus-made RTX 5060 Ti with just 8GB GDDR7, which we'd only recommend to players sticking with 1080p resolution and max 60 fps frame rates, but is a bit cheaper at $400 (was $470).

  • Asus TUF Gaming GeForce RTX 5070 12GB GDDR7 OC Edition -- $685 ($740)
  • Asus Dual GeForce RTX 5060 Ti 16GB GDDR7 OC Edition -- $430 ($480)
  • Asus Prime GeForce RTX 5060 Ti 8GB GDDR7 OC Edition -- $400 ($470)

Desktop PC Prime Day Deals

If you want to skip buying individual components, you can also grab one of several pre-made PC gaming desktops that are discounted for Prime Day. There's a wide range of models from various brands with different component load outs, but we've picked a few notable choices below.

  • Alienware Aurora ACT1250 Gaming PC - Intel Core Ultra 9 285 Liquid Cooled CPU, Nvidia GeForce RTX 5080 GPU, 32GB DDR5 RAM, 1TB SSD -- $2,500 ($3,000)
  • CyberPowerPC Gamer Master Gaming PC - AMD Ryzen 5 5500 3.6GHz CPU, Radeon RX 6400 4GB GPU, 16GB DDR4 RAM 500GB SSD -- $610 ($720)
  • iBuypower Y40 PRO Gaming PC - AMD Ryzen 9 7900X CPU, Nvidia GeForce RTX 5070Ti 16GB GPU, 32GB DDR5 RAM, 2TB SSD -- $1,955 ($2,300)
  • MSI Codex Z2 Gaming PC - AMD R7-8700F CPU, GeForce RTX 5070 GPU, 32GB DDR5 RAM, 2TB SSD -- $1,600 ($2,200)

item.title: Pokemon Go Solgaleo Raids: Best Counters, Weaknesses, And More Tips
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

A new raid boss has arrived in Pokemon Go. Solgaleo, the mascot of Pokemon Sun, is appearing in five-star raids until July 14, giving you a few days to add it to your collection.

While the legendary Pokemon has been available in the mobile game since 2022, this is the first time it's appearing as a raid boss. Previously, Solgaleo could only be obtained by evolving Cosmoem, so if you missed your chance to get a Cosmog, you now have the opportunity to catch one if you're able to defeat it in battle.

Like other legendaries, Solgaleo is a formidable opponent, so we've put together some tips to help you beat and catch the legendary Pokemon before it leaves raids next week.

  • How To Fuse With Necrozma

Solgaleo Raid Schedule

Solgaleo is appearing as a five-star raid boss from July 8 to 14, giving you less than a week to catch one before the next raid boss, Terrakion, replaces it.

Solgaleo raids will occur periodically throughout this time, but your best chance to join one will happen during the Solgaleo Raid Hour on July 9. The legendary Pokemon will take over most nearby gyms from 6 to 7 PM local time, giving you more opportunities than usual to battle and catch it.

Solgaleo Weaknesses

Despite its fiery appearance, Solgaleo is a psychic- and steel-type Pokemon, which makes it weak to only a handful of types.

Since psychic and steel don't share any vulnerabilities, no Pokemon type will deal quadruple damage to Solgaleo, but the following types will still dish out super-effective damage against the legendary Pokemon:

  • Fire
  • Ground
  • Ghost
  • Dark

Best Solgaleo Counters

Any Pokemon that has a type advantage over Solgaleo will be helpful when battling the legendary, but here are some recommended choices to use during a Solgaleo raid:

Types To Avoid

Thanks to its typing combination, Solgaleo resists a number of popular Pokemon types. Dragon, fairy, rock, grass, ice, and normal attacks will all deal half-damage, making them ineffective when battling the legendary Pokemon. Poison and other psychic types will deal even less damage, so you'll want to avoid using those Pokemon entirely when participating in a Solgaleo raid.

Can Solgaleo Be Shiny?

Unfortunately, shiny Solgaleo is not yet available in Pokemon Go, so you'll only encounter the standard white variant when you challenge one in raids. You can get a shiny Solgaleo in other Pokemon games like Pokemon Scarlet and Violet for Nintendo Switch, but you'll need to wait a little longer before you can add one to your collection in Pokemon Go.

How To Fuse With Necrozma

Solgaleo and its counterpart Lunala are unique among legendary Pokemon in that they're able to fuse with Necrozma, another legendary.

Once you've amassed enough Solar Fusion Energy, you can fuse Solgaleo with Necrozma to form Dusk Mane Necrozma. The fusion process costs 1,000 Fusion Energy, 30 Necrozma Candy, and 30 Cosmog Candy, and the two legendary Pokemon will remain fused until you manually separate them.

Dusk Mane Necrozma is a formidable Pokemon, maintaining Solgaleo's psychic/steel typing but gaining access to some powerful moves like Sunsteel Strike, a steel-type Charged Attack. This makes it a particularly good counter against fairy and ice Pokemon.

Solgaleo may leave raids on July 14, but there's still plenty to do in Pokemon Go over the next few weeks. Be sure to check out our Pokemon Go July events guide for a look at everything happening in the mobile game this month.

item.title: Subnautica 2 Delay May Cost Studio $250 Million Bonus - Report
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Earlier this month, the founders of Unknown Worlds--the studio behind Subnautica and its upcoming sequel, Subnautica 2--were reportedly forced out of the studio by parent company Krafton. Now, it's being alleged that Krafton's decision to delay Subnautica 2 into 2026 could cost developer Unknown Worlds' team a $250 million bonus.

According to Bloomberg, Unknown Worlds' ousted leaders--Subnautica director and designer Charlie Cleveland, Unknown Worlds co-founder Max McGuire, and CEO Ted Gill--were against delaying Subnautica 2. Cleveland recently shared his belief that Subnautica 2 is ready for early-release now, which was the original plan for the game's rollout this year.

Krafton was reportedly going to be on the hook for the $250 million bonus if Unknown Worlds reached revenue goals before the end of this year. But without Subnautica 2's early access release, those numbers are likely to fall short of those targets.

The report indicates that Unknown Worlds' former leaders planned to share the bonus with all of the studio's employees. Steve Papoutsis--the new CEO of Unknown Worlds--was reportedly asked about the bonus at a town hall meeting. Papoutsis is said to have replied that he wasn't told anything about the bonus and wasn't aware if it had been a factor in the decision to push back the game.

Krafton hasn't set a specific release date for Subnautica 2.
